title: Pregnancy and Future Heart Health

content: What happens during pregnancy may predict a person’s future health. Pregnancy tests the limits of the heart and blood vessels for 9 months and may indicate the body’s limited capacity to prevent chronic illness later on.

Increasingly, research is discovering that developing certain conditions at any time during pregnancy is an early warning sign for cardiovascular disease, often years after delivery. Preeclampsia, gestational diabetes, delivering a preterm baby, and pregnancy loss are particularly problematic to a person’s future health
Preeclampsia is when blood pressure is elevated on a regular basis during pregnancy, causing changes that are dangerous for mom and baby. Preeclampsia can also develop in the days after delivery.

Preeclampsia and other blood pressure disorders during pregnancy can have lingering effects. It’s likely that 20% of women with preeclampsia will develop high blood pressure within 15 years of pregnancy, even when blood pressure levels return to normal after giving birth.
Gestational diabetes is the type of diabetes that first occurs in pregnant people. About 8% of all U.S. pregnancies are affected by gestational diabetes .

content: Gestational diabetes increases the chances of developing type 2 diabetes by tenfold, and certain factors can make type 2 diabetes more likely.  In one study, the risk was higher in older moms, those with overweight, women who gave birth two or more times, those with a family history of diabetes, and in those who also had a preterm delivery.

In addition, women with gestational diabetes typically developed high blood pressure later on more often than those without diabetes. Over time, excessive blood glucose levels that result from type 2 diabetes damage blood vessels as well as the nerves that control your heart.

Preterm birth , which affects 1 in 10 pregnancies in the U.S., is when a baby is delivered before the end of the 37th week of pregnancy. The earlier a baby is born and the smaller they are at birth, the stronger the chances are that the mother will go on to have cardiovascular disease later.

content: Miscarriage is the loss of pregnancy at less than 20 weeks. In one study , women who experienced one early miscarriage (before the end of 12 weeks of pregnancy) had a small increase in the development of high blood pressure. However, those who had three or more early miscarriages experienced a much greater chance for developing high blood pressure compared to women who never had a miscarriage.  The same was true for type 2 diabetes risk – it was much greater in the group with three or more early miscarriages.

Stillbirth , the loss of a pregnancy after 20 weeks of pregnancy, also affects a mother’s future health. Research shows that type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure are more common in women who experienced stillbirth.

You can’t control everything that happens during pregnancy and you certainly can’t go back and change history. Having one or more pregnancy complications does not mean you will have health problems in the future, but it does serve as a heads up for managing your health going forward.

content: Adopt a heart-healthy eating plan that’s low in saturated fat and sodium and rich in fiber with the right number of calories to control your weight within a healthy range. Regular physical activity reduces the likelihood for cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes. Don’t smoke, and do what you can to manage your stress.
Above all, be your own health advocate. Discuss your pregnancy experiences with your doctor so that they can monitor your health on a regular basis as you age.
